instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Got another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that's not powering up. Initially, PP20V was 5v. Replaced UB300, which had a blowout on the surface. Once replaced, 20V was back. With the board back in the system, every few minutes or when I press the power Botton, the fan would spin up for about a second before it shuts off. I can also see a quick spike in current draw before it drops out. Here are the readings I have so far

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> - 12.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> - 12.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3HRTC_X</SIGNAL> - 12.6

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5.1
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> - 3.3

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_T_USBC</SIGNAL> - 0 (does not spike up when there board does draw current for a second)
<SIGNAL>UPC_T_5V_EN_R</SIGNAL> - 0 (does not spike up when there board does draw current for a second)


<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes to 3.4v for 10 seconds after 20v power kicks on then turns off after 5 seconds. 
<SIGNAL>UPC_T_5V_EN</SIGNAL> stays low the whole time

<SIGNAL>SMC_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> - also spikes to 1.79 but drops out within less than a second.
Same with <SIGNAL>SMC_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> stays at 1.79 for about 4 to 5 second before it drops out.

<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.9 during the current draw and drops to zero within a 2 seconds
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1 during current draw and drops to zero within a 2 seconds

What else should I check or any suggestions

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Test the board alone, no power button connected.
The board should start automatically, when charger is connected (battery removed).
For debugging, use SWK000/002 instead power button, to check signals reaction triggering <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

"<SIGNAL>SMC_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> stays at 1.79 for about 4 to 5"
Do you get <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>?
If yes, check if <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes high at same time.

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts (drop pulse) triggering <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, check for reaction at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> lines.
If not, check <SIGNAL>PCH_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.38. Drops to zero when SWK000 bridged.

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8 the whole time. Stays on from when the power is plugged to the board with PP20V @ 5v to when 20v is switch on. Never drops.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3 for about 5seconds before it drops. Also, it only goes high once the board starts to pull current, which is about 10sec after 20v becomes active to board is active.When I trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, it goes to 3.3 again for 5 seconds.

When <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> goes to 3.3 for about 10sec before it drops

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> - 1.8 for about 5 sec
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3 for about 2 sec

Also checked, <SIGNAL>PCH_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> which reacts the same 3.3 for about 5 sec.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Not sure if this is anything, should PP1V5R1V35_S0_GPU_MEM line on LA300 be at 217ohms?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Try to start in SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
I'm assuming I'll be using the <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

Still does the same current draw for a few seconds then back to 0A draw.

I did notice that <SIGNAL>CHGR_LX2</SIGNAL> - voltage is all over the place, between 3.3v and 12v

Since I didn't have a similar board to compare to, I used <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> circuit, which was similar to an extent. <SIGNAL>TBA_LX2</SIGNAL> was constant at 13v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
"When <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> goes to 3.3 for about 10sec before it drops"
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts (drop pulse) if you trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> in these 10s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: when <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered again within the 10s, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops to 0 during the trigger, but then back to 3.3 for another 10sec

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3 for about 2 sec"
Each of them enables a sleep state; something like Sx --> (Sx-1).
Check S4/3/0 voltages in these 2 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_T_USBC</SIGNAL> - never triggers. So check <SIGNAL>UPC_T_5V_EN_R</SIGNAL>, this too never triggers. On UB740, only <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> triggers 3.3v for about 5sec. <SIGNAL>UPC_T_5V_EN</SIGNAL> never turns on. Wondering if i should change out the USBC chip that i had replaced.

Same readings on X line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Replaced the chip again with the same result. S4 still isn't coming on. Regarding your last post, unlike previous version boards, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> for example, the power Power Alias pages doesn't calls out S3 and S0 lines.
Here are the readings i collected:

[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.995[/COLOR]  for about 2 sec (schematic calls for 1.52v)
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.044 for 2 sec (schematic calls for 1.52v)
[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.0[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.94 for 2 sec 
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.2 2 sec
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> - 1.2 2 sec
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 1.2 2 sec
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM</SIGNAL> - 1.05 for 5 sec
[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> - 0[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW</SIGNAL> 1.04 2 sec
[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 0[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 3.3 2 sec
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> 1.8 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5.1 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> - 3.4 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.4 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> - 3.3 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_X</SIGNAL> - 3.4 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL> - 3.3 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL> - 3.3 2 sec 
PPVCCPRIMCORE_PRIM_REG - 1.05 5 sec
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_DFR</SIGNAL> - 3.3 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> - 3.3 the whole time
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> - 12.5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
"[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> - 0"
Check diode mode there.
This voltage must appear before <SIGNAL>1V05_S0SW</SIGNAL>...[/COLOR]

"[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.0"
iGPU power stays at 0V untill open graphics application on iGPU, like YouTube playing...
Board starts with dGPU normally.[/COLOR]

BTW, CPU voltages are dinamycally adjusted, as seen on the power supplies pages, not in power aliases one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> - 0.197

I must have missed the reading the first time cause <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> now shows 1.05 for 2 sec. Sorry bout that
